metadata.case_name: Singareni Collieries Company Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: The appellant Company has its registered office at Hyderabad in the former Part B State of Hyderabad and mines coal from its collieries and supplies it to consumers within and outside the State of Hyderabad.

These appeals relate to financial years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57, during which coal was a controlled commodity and its disposal and use could be made only under orders issued by the appropriate authority under the Colliery Control Order, 1945.

The Company claimed Rs. 1,75,67,286/1/2 in 1954-55, Rs. 1,17,39,636/11/8 in 1955-56, and Rs. 1,55,18,937/6/5 in 1956-57 were not liable to be included in taxable turnover under Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950, due to Art. 286 prohibiting tax on supplies outside the State.
Commercial Tax Officer, Hyderabad, admitted the claim for 1954-55 and 1955-56 but rejected for 1956-57.
Company appealed to Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and Sales-tax Appellate Tribunal against 1956-57 assessment, but appeals failed.
Company applied to Andhra Pradesh High Court in revisional jurisdiction claiming exemption under Art. 286(1)(a) Explanation and as inter-State sales.
High Court rejected contentions in T.R.C. No. 17 of 1960 and Special Appeals Nos. 1 & 2 of 1961 dated November 15, 1960 and July 25, 1961.
Commissioner of Commercial Taxes issued notices to reopen assessments for 1954-55 and 1955-56, orders dated February 8, 1961 and November 16, 1960 bringing exempted turnover to tax.
Appeals against reopening orders to High Court, raising same grounds plus limitation bar; High Court rejected.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

Under Colliery Control Order, 1945: Government fixes prices (cl.4), prohibits selling above price (cl.5), direct sales with consent (cl.6), directions for disposal (cl.8,9), diversion in transit (cl.10-A), restrictions on use/disposal (cl.12-B,12-E).

Coal Commissioner authorizes colliery to dispatch coal to specified consumers per schedule; consumer requests dispatch; colliery issues sale note F.O.R. Colliery, loads in wagons, dispatches to destination.
Sale note terms: Property passes on loading to wagons; colliery not responsible for non-delivery/loss after; taxes after sale note borne by purchaser; subject to allotment cancellation.
Coal supplied to allottees outside State for consumption there.
Periods: Apr 1,1954-Sep 6,1955; Sep7,1955-Sep10,1956; Sep11,1956-Jan4,1957; Jan5,1957-Mar31,1957. States Reorganisation Act effective Nov 1,1956 affected Hyderabad.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transactions of sale of coal supplied to allottees outside the taxing State pursuant to directions of the Coal Commissioner are hit by Art. 286(1)(a) Explanation as outside sales.
Whether the transactions were sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce hit by Art. 286(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: No sale under Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act for supplies pursuant to Coal Commissioner directions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. CST Bihar

petitioner_arguments.text: Turnover exempt as sales outside State under Art. 286(1)(a) Explanation and in course of inter-State trade/commerce.
Reopening of assessments for 1954-55 and 1955-56 barred by limitation.

respondent_arguments.text: Coal dispatched from taxing State was actually delivered within taxing State (to railway).

court_reasoning.text: Assumes transactions are sales under general law; no need to consider no-sale argument as not raised earlier.
For all periods, sales covered by Art. 286(1)(a) Explanation: actual delivery for consumption is outside State, not mere delivery to carrier; property passage immaterial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Physical delivery or possession to purchaser required; loading to railway not actual delivery within Explanation.

court_reasoning.text: Transactions are inter-State sales: movement from one State to another incident to contract of sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale occasions movement of goods across States.

court_reasoning.text: Period Apr1,1954-Sep6,1955: Validation Act removed Art.286(2) ban retrospectively, but Explanation applies exempting outside sales.
Sep7,1955-Sep10,1956: Exempt under Explanation and Art.286(2) ban on inter-State.
Sep11,1956-Jan4,1957: Art.286(2) repealed, no State power over inter-State sales.
Jan5,1957-Mar31,1957: Central Sales Tax Act governs inter-State sales; State has no power.
No need to decide reopening validity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in holding taxable.

holdings.text: Sales of coal to outside allottees not taxable under Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act as outside sales per Art.286(1)(a) Explanation.
Transactions are inter-State sales not taxable by State during relevant periods.

precedents_cited.case_name: New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied for no-sale argument, but not considered.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286 clauses deal with different topics; no State tax on inter-State sales until Parliament provides; Explanation not extends to cl.2.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shree Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Actual delivery means physical delivery for consumption; not symbolic to carrier.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. S. R. Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Inter-State sale if movement result of covenant/incident of contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: State Trading Corporation of India Ltd. v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Reaffirmed Tata Iron test for inter-State sales.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cement Marketing Co. of India v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Reaffirmed Tata Iron test for inter-State sales.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of 'sale'; excludes transfers immune under Art.286.

statutes_cited.name: Colliery Control Order, 1945
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulated supply, disposal, use of coal; basis of transactions.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits State tax on outside sales (Expl. to 1(a)), inter-State sales (cl.2); amended by Sixth Amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospectively validated State taxes on inter-State sales Apr1,1951-Sep6,1955.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Sixth Amendment) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended Art.286; added Entry 92A List I.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines inter-State sales; vests taxing power centrally from Jan5,1957.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: General law on passing of property not governs constitutional situs.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment set aside; declared that turnover of Rs. 1,75,67,286/1/2 for 1954-55, Rs. 1,17,39,636/11/8 for 1955-56, and Rs. 1,55,18,937/6/5 for 1956-57 not taxable under Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950.
outcome.relief_granted: Exemption from sales tax on disputed turnover declared.

key_quotes.text: "a sale falls within the Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) if goods have actually been delivered as a direct result of the sale for the purpose of consumption in the State in which they are delivered... actual delivery... can only mean physical delivery of the goods, or such other action as puts the goods in the possession of the purchaser."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'actual delivery' under Explanation, key to outside sales.

key_quotes.text: "The expression actually delivered does not include mere symbolical or notional delivery e.g. by entrusting the goods to a common carrier."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes delivery to railway from actual delivery for consumption.

key_quotes.text: "A sale could be said to begin the course of inter-State trade only if two conditions occur: (1) a sale of goods, and (2) a transport of those goods from one State to another under the contract of sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for inter-State sales from Bengal Immunity.

key_quotes.text: "The High Court was, in our view, in error in holding that the turnover of the Company in which coal was loaded in railway wagons for conveyance to places outside the taxing State was taxable under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
